questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following statements is false regarding the anatomy of the anal canal below the 
pectinate line?

options.a: Lymphatic drainage is to inguinal nodes
options.b: Innervation is by the inferior rectal nerves
options.c: Venous drainage is into the systemic circulation
options.d: Tumors are more likely to be adenocarcinoma

questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinoma is more likely to be seen above the pectinate line. Tumors below the pectinate 
line are more likely to be squamous cell carcinoma. The pectinate line is at the junction of the upper two-thirds and the lower one-third of the anal 
canal. Developmentally, it represents the hindgut–proctodeum junction. The part of the anal canal 
above this line developed from the hindgut and the part below developed from the proctodeum. 622 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following are not true regarding external hemorrhoids?
questions.explanation:
External hemorrhoids are painful, self-curing and covered by squamous epithelium. The branches 
of the superior rectal vein, located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal are common 
sites for internal hemorrhoids. Banding is preferred for internal hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle 
fibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types: • Internal Hemorrhoids • External Hemorrhoids Note: Repeated thrombosis leads to a semi-ripe black currant appearance of external 
hemorrhoids. 623 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following will you not consider as a differential in a patient presenting with 
anorectal pain?
questions.explanation: Internal hemorrhoids are painless. Causes of anorectal pain: • External hemorrhoids • Anal fissure • Proctalgia fugax • Levator ani syndrome • Fistula in ano/anal abscess • Inflammatory bowel disease • Coccydynia • Prostatitis • Carcinoma anus/lower rectum

questions.question:
Question 4: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of painless bleeding during 
defecation. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is 
asked to strain. It reduces spontaneously when the patient relaxes. What will be the grade of 614 
Sold by @itachibot this hemorrhoid?
questions.explanation: Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

questions.question:
Question 5: A man presented with bleeding per rectum which he noticed after passing stools for the past 2 
weeks. On straining, a reddish mass as shown in the image was seen protruding out of the 
anal canal. It did not reduce spontaneously and had to be manually reduced. What is the 
grade of hemorrhoids in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, as the prolapsed haemorrhoids required manual reduction, it is suggestive 
of third-degree haemorrhoids.

questions.question: Question 6: In patients with which of the following conditions can injection sclerotherapy be ideally used?
questions.explanation:
Injection sclerotherapy is ideal for the treatment of first and second-degree hemorrhoids (bleeding 
or spontaneously reducing hemorrhoids). 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) is 
injected into the submucosa of each hemorrhoid. Complications of sclerotherapy include infection 
and fibrosis.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe anorectal pain during and after 
defecation. The pain was present for 6 months but has increased in severity over the past 1 
day. Examination finding is shown below. A per-rectal examination could not be performed 
due to pain. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
624 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Patients 
who present within 48 hours of thrombosis should undergo thrombus evacuation under local 
anesthesia. This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin. After the initial 48-72 hours, pain typically plateaus and hence the patient is treated 
conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated 
with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, 
and cryotherapy. Surgery is indicated in: • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component • Early grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures Surgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are: • Open (Milligan–Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy • Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy - is circumferential rectal mucosectomy. It is associated with reduced 
postoperative pain, faster recovery and shorter hospital stay • Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation Open hemorrhoidectomy - Artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of 
the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral 
pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact 
in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. Closed hemorrhoidectomy - The hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The 
hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. This 
technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. This procedure is however quick to 
perform and less painful. The image below describes the procedure. 625 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy?
questions.explanation:
Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy. Conventional hemorrhoidectomy(open or closed technique), is considered to be an extremely 
painful procedure. Dysfunction of the detrusor muscle or the trigone in response to pain or 
distention of the anal canal or perineum has been postulated as the cause of urinary retention 
post hemorrhoidectomy. Other complications include: • Fecal incontinence • Infection • Delayed hemorrhage • Stricture

questions.question:
Question 9: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of chronic constipation, blood-streaked stools, and 
pain during defecation for 2 months. On examination, a sentinel tag was noted at the anal 
orifice. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the presence of a sentinel tag is suggestive of chronic anal fissure. An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate line 
extending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic. Chronic anal fissures last for more than 6-8 weeks, and are frequently associated with a triad of 
findings: • Sentinel tag • Hypertrophied anal papillae at the upper end of the fissure in the anal canal • Deep canoe-shaped ulcer 626 
Sold by @itachibot Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with: • Anal pain • Spasm • Bleeding with defecation The below image shows features of a chronic anal fissure

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common location of anal fissures?
questions.explanation:
Over 90% of fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the 
anterior midline of the anal canal. The main hypothesis is that the posterior midline area may have decreased blood flow due to the 
configuration of the blood vessels of the anus. Also, the spasm of the internal anal sphincter may 
cause further reduction of the blood flow to the posterior anal canal.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the procedure of choice in a patient with chronic anal fissure?
questions.explanation:
Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for chronic anal fissures. Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failed 
medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by 
dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided 
laterally using an open or closed technique. The initial treatment of anal fissures includes: • Frequent sitz baths • Analgesics 627 
Sold by @itachibot • Stool softeners • High-fiber diet If conservative management with dietary changes and laxatives fail, other options including 
topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a 
combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted. Option A: Miligan-Morgan procedure is an open hemorrhoidectomy Option C: Transanal resection is used to remove early-stage rectal cancers in the lower rectum Option D: Altermeier's procedure is used for rectal prolapse

questions.question:
Question 12: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image? 617 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between 
the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is 
the most common anal fistula. A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients 
usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or 
complex fistulas. • Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% 
of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. • Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with 
multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as 
Crohn disease and radiation treatment. Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect 
to the puborectalis muscle. 628 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the perianal 
region for the past 1 week. On examination, an external opening was seen at 2 o'clock position 
around the anal orifice. On per rectal examination, an opening was palpable at 3 o'clock 
position at the dentate line. What is the gold standard investigation for assessing this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of an anal fistula. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold 
standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps to identify the secondary extensions of the 
track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. Investigations available for fistula-in-ano are: • Fistulogram • Endoanal ultrasound • MRI • Computed tomography (CT) scan • Endocoil MRI • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. On 
examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. According to 
Goodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position 
which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. According 
to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to 
the posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6’O clock position. A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that 
connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. Goodsall’s rule: • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial 
tract. • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior 
midline. However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater 
than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline 629 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A known case of Crohn's disease presented to the clinic with a history of discharge from the 
anal region for the past 2 weeks. The patient underwent drainage of an ischiorectal abscess 2 
months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a supra-sphincteric 
perianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, a history of Crohn's disease, recurrent anorectal abscess, and the imaging 
findings point towards a complex anal fistula. It will be managed using Seton's placement, which 
is done in two stages. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can 
be classified as draining or cutting. Cutting seton A cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric 
fistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regular 
intervals, till it cuts through completely. 630 
Sold by @itachibot Loose/draining seton In this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the 
sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting. Option B: Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphincter 
muscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement. Option C: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is a technique used for chronic anal fissures. Option D: In fistulectomy, the fistulous tract is cut out completely. Other surgeries for fistula in-ano include: • Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridement 
of the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done for 
complex fistulas. • LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal opening 
with suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland are 
then excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple and 
complex fistulas.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is the most common cause of anorectal suppuration?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of anorectal suppuration is nonspecific cryptoglandular infection. Anorectal abscess originates from an infection arising in the cryptoglandular epithelium lining the 
anal canal. The increased incidence of ischio-rectal fossa infection is due to poor blood supply. It may also be caused by other reasons such as: • Crohn's disease • Trauma 631 
Sold by @itachibot • Immunodeficiency resulting from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or malignancy 
(both hematologic and anorectal cancer) • Tuberculosis • Hidradenitis suppurativa

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal abscess?
questions.explanation:
A perianal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess. Anorectal abscess refers to a collection of pus in the anal or rectal region. More commonly seen in 
men. There are four types of anorectal abscesses: • Peri-anal (most common) • Ischio-rectal • Inter-sphincteric • Supra-levator Treatment: Drainage of pus + Antibiotics

questions.question:
Question 18: 619 
Sold by @itachibot A jeep driver presented with a swelling in the natal cleft, with pain, difficulty in sitting, and 
occasional purulent discharge from the area. Examination finding is shown below. Which of 
the following is not true regarding this condition?

options.b: Hair follicles are seen in the wall of sinus
options.c: Hirsute habitus is a risk factor
options.d: Commonly seen between the ages of 15 and 40 years

questions.explanation:
The given condition is a pilonidal sinus. Hair follicles have almost never been demonstrated in the 
walls of the sinus. The hair projecting from the sinus is dead hair, with its pointed ends directed 
towards the blind end of the sinus. Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of a 
sinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age. Risk factors include: 632 
Sold by @itachibot • Male sex • Family history • Being overweight or obese • Trauma or irritation to the perianal region • Occupations involving sitting for long periods- jeep/lorry drivers • Hirsute habitus - thick body hair • Poor hygiene Sites involved: • Natal cleft (most commonly) • Interdigital cleft • Face • Axilla Buttock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create 
a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a 
track. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge. Clinical features: • Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine • Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reaction Treatment • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. • Abscess: • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and 
hair. • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease. Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus diseases?
questions.explanation:
Surgical approaches parallel to the natal cleft, and not along the natal cleft are preferred, to 
reduce chances of recurrence. Pilonidal sinus disease treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches. The non-surgical 
approach includes conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the 
area. In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum 
antibiotics are advised. 633 
Sold by @itachibot Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include: • Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment • Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are 
removed under local anesthesia • Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a 
fasciocutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect • Limberg/ rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a 
fasciocutaneous flap for wound closure • Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty The given image shows a Limberg/rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery:

questions.question:
Question 20: An elderly female presented with severe persisting per rectal itching for the past 1 year, 
despite standard topical therapy. On examination, irregular eczematous lesions were seen at 
the anal orifice. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells containing mucin. Which 
of the following is it likely to be? 620 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given history and presence of large vacuolated cells (Paget cells) on biopsy is suggestive of 
Paget's disease of the anal canal. It is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma. Paget’s disease is most commonly seen in areas with a high density of apocrine sweat glands, in 
elderly females. These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands. Clinical features include intractable itching, burning, bleeding per rectally. 10% of the patients are 
asymptomatic. On examination, eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulceration 
and scaling can be seen. On histology presence of Paget cells (large, vacuolated cells with mucin) confirms the diagnosis. Treatment: • Treatment of choice- complete excision • Limited, noninvasive disease-wide local excision and closure of the defect with primary sutures 
or with V-Y advancement flaps 634 
Sold by @itachibot • Invasive component- radical resection with abdominoperineal resection (APR) • Medically unfit for surgery - topical 5-FU, imiquimod, cryotherapy, or argon beam laser therapy • Recurrence- re-excision (as long as the disease remains noninvasive) Note: Most common site of extra-mammary Paget’s disease – anogenital region > axilla > 
eyelid. Perianal Paget’s disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, most 
commonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?

options.a: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
options.c: Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
options.d: Most common type of anal canal carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cell 
carcinoma >Melanoma The median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleeding 
per rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph node 
metastasis is to inguinal lymph nodes. Risk Factors: • Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression • Smoking • Anal receptive intercourse • Sexual promiscuity • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia • History of vulvar or cervical cancer Diagnosis: • Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice • MRI- for local staging • CT scan- to evaluate for distant metastasis Treatment : • Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice • If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is

questions.question:
Question 22: A 60-year-old man with bleeding per rectum is suspected to have squamous cell carcinoma of 
the anal canal. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

options.d: Surgical excision with CO2 laser treatment

questions.explanation:
Treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is Nigro regimen/ 
chemoradiation. A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam 
radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following is true about melanoma of the anal canal?
questions.explanation:
Anorectal melanoma is staged by the depth or thickness of the lesion. Anal canal melanoma is more common in females. The tumor appears as small and polypoidal or 
large and ulcerating. Clinical features include: • Anorectal bleeding, itching, pain, mass 636 
Sold by @itachibot • Tenesmus, and changes in bowel habits • Mesorectal lymph node metastases • Inguinal lymphadenopathy • Distant spread- to bones, lungs, and liver Diagnosis is frequently made following hemorrhoidectomy or local excision of the perianal mass. Treatment: • Tumors without anal sphincter involvement- wide local excision with negative margins • Large tumors invading sphincters- palliative APR Regardless of stage, 5-year survival rates for anorectal melanoma are very poor, averaging at 
about 6%. The median survival time following diagnosis is 12–18 months. Note: Most common sites of melanoma are skin >eye > anorectal region 637 
Sold by @itachibot Hernia
